The decision is made to provide supplemental oxygen via a nasal cannula. What is the maximum flow rate at which a nasal cannula can effectively deliver oxygen before causing significant patient discomfort and nasal dryness?
Which of the following is not a feature of Proliferation phase of wound healing?
questions.correct_answer: D. Matrix Metalloproteinase activity is more.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an X ray finding of hyperparathyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Ground glass appearance of outer 2/3rd of skull.

options.label: D
options.text: Reabsorption of proximal end of long bones.

questions.text: A male patient aged 30 years following a road traffic accident presents with fracture of 4th to 10th ribs and respiratory distress. He is diagnosed to have flail chest and PaO2 is less than 60%. The treatment of choice is
The term “minimal brain dysfunction” was used to describe? (NEET)

A 25 year old soccer player complained of injury to right knee 6 months ago. Now he says that there is a feeling of sudden giving away of knee joint with knee in 90 degree flexion which completely disappears when the knee is taken into complete extension. Which of the following ligament needs to be checked?
Metabolism of local anaesthetics depends on chemical structure.which of the following statements about the same are true?

options.label: A
options.text: Amide local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized by plasma cholinesterase

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolism of bupivacaine is independent of hepatic function

options.label: C
options.text: Ester local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized in by kidneys.

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolites from ester hydrolysis are excreted in the urine

questions.correct_answer: D. Metabolites from ester hydrolysis are excreted in the urine

questions.text: False statement about papillary thyroid cancer?
questions.correct_answer: D. Hurthle cell is a subtype

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with severe headache, vomiting, blurred vision, and altered mental status. His blood pressure is recorded as 180/120 mmHg (>99th percentile + 30 mmHg for age and height). Fundoscopy shows bilateral papilledema, and there is a mild elevation of serum creatinine. He is diagnosed with hypertensive emergency. The pediatric ICU is alerted and intravenous antihypertensive therapy is initiated. You are consulted for advice on how rapidly his blood pressure should be lowered to prevent complications such as cerebral hypoperfusion, seizures, and further renal damage. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding the initial reduction in blood pressure in this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Lower by 10% in the first hour

options.label: B
options.text: Lower by 15% in the first hour

options.label: C
options.text: Lower by 15% over the first 8 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Lower by 25% over the first 2 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Lower by 10% in the first hour

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely finding with the specimen shown below
30-year-old primigravida delivers the fetal head, but it retracts against the perineum. McRoberts maneuver and suprapubic pressure fail. What is the next best step?

30-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. HSG reveals a distended fallopian tube with a “beads-on-string” appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis, and its most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrosalpinx; consider laparoscopic salpingectomy before IVF

questions.correct_answer: B. Hydrosalpinx; consider laparoscopic salpingectomy before IVF

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought with a history of brief flexor spasms occurring in clusters, especially on awakening. Developmental regression has been noted by the parents. EEG reveals a chaotic, high-voltage, disorganized pattern with multifocal spikes — a finding known as hypsarrhythmia. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
According to Indian national guidelines, which of the following is the preferred corticosteroid regimen for promoting fetal lung maturity in preterm labor?

options.label: A
options.text: Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses

options.label: B
options.text: Dexamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for 4 doses

options.label: C
options.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses

options.label: D
options.text: Betamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for 4 doses

questions.correct_answer: B. Dexamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for 4 doses

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with 5 months of right shoulder pain, swelling, and ulnar neuropathy. Following the shoulder radiograph, an MR is obtained. What is the unifying diagnosis?
Which of the following is NOT a component of Active Management of Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) as per WHO recommendations?

options.label: A
options.text: Administration of oxytocin within 1 minute of delivery

options.label: C
options.text: Delayed cord clamping for at least 1–3 minutes

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient on ski vacation brought to emergency room for acute respiratory distress. What is the most likely diagnosis?
30-year-old woman with MCDA twins at 28 weeks is noted to have intertwin hemoglobin discordance with normal amniotic fluid volumes in both sacs. What is the likely diagnosis?
22-year-old woman with primary infertility undergoes HSG, which shows the following. Which of the following is the most commonly associated anomaly?

options.label: A
options.text: Renal agenesis on the same side

questions.correct_answer: A. Renal agenesis on the same side

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with cirrhosis develops worsening dyspnea. High-resolution CT shows diffuse ground-glass opacities superimposed by interlobular septal thickening (“crazy-paving”). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old woman undergoing ovulation induction for IVF presents with abdominal distension, nausea, and shortness of breath 6 days after hCG trigger. Ultrasound shows the following. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism in this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased capillary permeability due to VEGF

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased capillary permeability due to VEGF

questions.text: Which of the following events occurs by the end of the first week of embryonic development post-fertilization?

options.label: B
options.text: Differentiation of the three germ layers

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with infertility. He has small, firm testes, gynecomastia, and sparse facial hair. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. Serum FSH and LH are elevated, and testosterone is low. What is the most likely karyotype, and what is a common associated finding?
questions.correct_answer: B. 47,XXY; increased risk of breast cancer

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation visits the antenatal clinic for a routine check-up. On abdominal examination, the uterus appears smaller than expected for gestational age (corresponding to 16 weeks). Ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios, but fetal heart activity is present. Which of the following fetal conditions is the most likely cause of this finding?

A pediatrician is explaining patterns of inheritance to medical students using examples of genetic disorders. She describes a condition that commonly presents with recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and steatorrhea in early childhood. The disorder is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene and follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Which of the following conditions best fits this description?

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric genetics clinic due to developmental delay, hypotonia, and insatiable appetite that has resulted in rapid weight gain over the last year. He was born at term following an uneventful pregnancy and showed poor feeding in the neonatal period. On examination, he has almond-shaped eyes, a narrow bifrontal diameter, and small hands and feet. There is no history of seizures. Genetic testing reveals a deletion in the paternal copy of chromosome 15q11–q13. The physician explains to the parents that this condition is due to a genetic phenomenon involving parent-of-origin specific gene expression. Which of the following conditions shares a similar mechanism involving genomic imprinting?

A 26-year-old woman complains of frothy greenish vaginal discharge with a foul odor and severe vulvar itching. On speculum exam, the cervix shows following appearance. What is the next best step in diagnosis?
Which of the following statements about Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis (PGD) is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: PGD can only be performed after embryo implantation in the uterus

options.label: B
options.text: PGD is primarily used to assess chromosomal aneuploidies in naturally conceived pregnancies

options.label: C
options.text: PGD requires in vitro fertilization and is typically done on blastomeres or trophectoderm cells

options.label: D
options.text: PGD is contraindicated in couples with known monogenic disorders

questions.correct_answer: C. PGD requires in vitro fertilization and is typically done on blastomeres or trophectoderm cells

questions.text: 65-year-old woman with a history of vaginal hysterectomy 10 years ago now presents with a sensation of vaginal bulge and incomplete bowel emptying. Examination reveals vault prolapse. Which of the following is the most definitive surgical management?

32-year-old woman in her third trimester becomes lightheaded and nauseous when lying flat for an ultrasound. Her BP drops to 80/50 mmHg. She recovers quickly when turned to the left lateral position. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased sympathetic tone due to progesterone

options.label: B
options.text: Compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Aorto-caval compression leading to reduced uterine blood flow

questions.correct_answer: B. Compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of hearing concerns. The parents report that the baby does not respond to sounds or turn the head toward voices. On examination, bilateral lens opacities (cataracts) are noted, and a cardiac murmur is heard. Echocardiography confirms the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). There is no history of perinatal complications or NICU stay. Antenatal records show the mother had a mild febrile illness with rash in the first trimester. The clinician suspects a congenital infection as the underlying cause of the multisystem involvement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the most common long-term complication of the condition shown below
According to the current Indian national guidelines (MOHFW), which of the following statements about antenatal care is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Iron-folic acid supplementation should begin from the third trimester

options.label: B
options.text: A minimum of 6 antenatal visits are recommended, starting after the second trimester

options.label: C
options.text: Tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine is given only once in each pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: First antenatal check-up should ideally be done within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. First antenatal check-up should ideally be done within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: A full-term newborn is evaluated at 24 hours of life. The baby is active, feeding well on exclusive breastfeeding, and has stable vital signs. However, the parents are concerned because the baby has not passed urine since birth. There is no abdominal distension, vomiting, or signs of dehydration. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Admit to NICU and start antibiotics

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, 3 days postpartum, presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and foul-smelling lochia. Uterus is tender and subinvoluted. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-month-old infant, born to an HIV-positive mother, presents with recurrent diarrhea. The baby was exclusively breastfed and has no other significant medical history. On examination, the infant is mildly dehydrated but hemodynamically stable. Given the age and high-risk background, what is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this child?

options.label: B
options.text: HIV PCR on dried blood spot

options.label: D
options.text: IgM for giardiasis and start antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: B. HIV PCR on dried blood spot

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks gestation is diagnosed with HIV. Her viral load is 900 copies/mL and CD4 count is 420 cells/mm³. She is not on ART. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start ART immediately and plan elective cesarean at 38 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Delay ART until 34 weeks and plan for vaginal delivery

options.label: C
options.text: Start ART immediately and allow vaginal delivery irrespective of viral load

options.label: D
options.text: ART not needed as CD4 count is >200 and viral load is low

questions.correct_answer: C. Start ART immediately and allow vaginal delivery irrespective of viral load

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has no secondary sexual characteristics. Height is below the 3rd percentile, and she has a webbed neck and shield chest. all the following are true about this condition except

options.label: C
options.text: High risk of coarctation of aorta

questions.correct_answer: D. High risk of gonadal malignancy

questions.text: Most common fetal complication of vacuum delivery is:

A 1-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with a 2-day history of diarrhea. On examination, the child is lethargic, unable to drink or feed, and has a skin pinch that goes back slowly. Mucous membranes are dry and the child has sunken eyes. Based on WHO classification of dehydration, what is the most appropriate classification of this child’s hydration status?
A male patient with diarrhea since 8months with shown CT finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is contraindication for performing dilatation and curettage (D&C)?

options.label: D
options.text: Postmenopausal bleeding with endometrial thickness of 15 mm

questions.text: Primigravida in labor is found to have a fetus in vertex presentation with occiput posterior position and deflexion of the head. Which of the following is the most likely engaging diameter of the fetal head in this case?
Most useful investigation for localization of parathyroid adenoma:

A preterm newborn presents within the first few hours of life with signs of respiratory distress, including chest retractions, nasal flaring, tachypnea, and lethargy. The oxygen saturation is low despite supplemental oxygen. Chest X-ray shows a reticulogranular pattern with air bronchograms. The pediatrician suspects Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS). Further review of the baby's antenatal history reveals no antenatal corticosteroid administration. The diagnosis is confirmed, and the cause is identified as a deficiency of a key component that reduces alveolar surface tension, leading to alveolar collapse. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this condition?
Best initial treatment for mild to moderate endometriosis in a woman not seeking fertility:
Which of the following surgical procedure will you do for the Müllerian anomaly shown below

A 13-year-old girl presents with cyclical lower abdominal pain for 6 months and has not attained menarche. She has normal secondary sexual characteristics. On examination, a tender pelvic mass is palpable, and bluish bulging membrane is seen at the vaginal introitus. What is the most likely immediate complication if left untreated?
